fullText:
Bulletin of Mathematical Biology (2006) 68: 1–1
DOI 10.1007/s11538-006-9081-0
EDITORIAL
Editorial
Philip K. Maini
Centre for Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford,
Oxford, OX1 3LB, UK
Published online: March 28 2006
C© Society for Mathematical Biology 2006
Welcome to the new look Bulletin of Mathematical Biology which is now be-
ing published by Springer. As you probably know Springer has a long history of
publishing in mathematics, and specifically in mathematical biology hence I think
this will be a good partnership for both Springer and the Society. Under Springer,
the journal will increase the number of pages published per year, as well as install
a manuscript tracking system to speed up publication of articles. Papers will be
published Online First in full text via Springerlink, Springer’s electronic journal
platform, which can presently be accessed by around 5000 institutions worldwide.
Papers will be assigned DOI numbers when they are published online allowing
them to be citable.
Another new feature includes submission of ancillary materials, such as video,
illustrations, data sets, etc. which may be submitted for online publication with
your article. These materials are subject to review and approval of the editorial
staff, and should be included with article submission.
As we all know, Mathematical Biology is one of the fastest growing fields in
science today. As evidence of that, the submission rate to the Bulletin has doubled
over the past four years. In order to reduce publication times the Bulletin will
now be published eight times a year. The healthy state of the journal is due in no
small part to the previous Editor, Lee Segel. He was one of the founder members
of modern Mathematical Biology and contributed seminal research in a number of
diverse areas. Simultaneously, the Bulletin of Mathematical Biology became one of
the main journals in the area under his editorship. In recognition of Lee’s immense
contribution to the field Springer has kindly offered to fund a series of prizes in
his memory linked to papers published in the journal. There will be three prize
categories: best original research student paper (awarded every two years); best
original research paper (awarded every two years); best review paper (awarded
every three years).
This is an exciting time for the journal and I look forward to working with the
Springer team.
